title: The Analects (Lunyu)
subtitle: Conversations and Sayings of the Master
summary: A compilation of conversations, teachings, and sayings of Confucius and his disciples, forming the foundation of Confucian thought and ethics.
keyConceptExplanation: The highest virtue encompassing humaneness, kindness, and moral goodness toward all people

sections.title: The Joy of Learning
sections.content: Learning and practicing what is learned brings joy. True education involves both acquiring knowledge and applying it in daily life for moral cultivation.

sections.title: Filial Piety (Xiao)
sections.content: Respect and care for parents and elders is the root of all virtue. 'When a father's way is not righteous, a son cannot refrain from protesting.'

sections.title: The Gentleman (Junzi)
sections.content: The ideal person who cultivates virtue, acts with righteousness, and serves as a moral exemplar. 'The gentleman understands what is right; the petty person understands what is profitable.'

sections.title: Proper Conduct (Li)
sections.content: Ritual propriety and social etiquette maintain harmony in relationships and society. 'Without proper conduct, reverence becomes wearisome, caution becomes timidity.'

funFacts: Compiled by disciples after Confucius's death, not by the Master himself
Contains only fragments and short sayings, no systematic treatise
Basis for Chinese civil service examinations for over 1,300 years
The Golden Rule appears here: 'Do not impose on others what you do not wish for yourself'

keyPrinciples.explanation: Continuous moral and intellectual development throughout life
Individual virtue contributes to societal order and peace
Treat others as you would wish to be treated

title: The Great Learning (Daxue)
subtitle: The Gateway to Moral Cultivation
summary: Originally a chapter in the Book of Rites, this text outlines the process of moral and intellectual cultivation from personal development to governing others.
keyConceptExplanation: A systematic progression from investigating things to achieving universal peace through moral development

sections.title: Investigation of Things
sections.content: Knowledge begins with careful observation and study of the natural and social world. Understanding principles leads to wisdom.

sections.title: Extension of Knowledge
sections.content: From investigation comes genuine knowledge. This knowledge must be extended and applied to understand moral principles.

sections.title: Sincerity of Intention
sections.content: The heart-mind must be made sincere. Self-deception destroys moral cultivation - one must be honest with oneself.

sections.title: From Personal to Universal
sections.content: Moral cultivation extends outward: cultivate yourself, regulate the family, order the state, achieve universal peace.

funFacts: Attributed to Confucius with commentary by his disciple Zengzi
Became one of the Four Books selected by Zhu Xi
The phrase 'Great Learning' refers to adult education in moral cultivation
Influenced Neo-Confucian philosophy during Song dynasty

keyPrinciples.explanation: Personal cultivation is the root; governing others is the branch
Internal moral development must align with external actions
Moral cultivation follows a logical sequence of stages

title: Doctrine of the Mean (Zhongyong)
subtitle: The Perfect Balance
summary: Attributed to Confucius's grandson Zisi, this work explores the metaphysical foundations of Confucian ethics and the ideal of perfect harmony.
keyConceptExplanation: The perfect balance and harmony that comes from following the natural way ordained by Heaven

sections.title: The Way of Heaven
sections.content: Heaven's way is constant and perfect. Humans must align themselves with this cosmic principle to achieve moral perfection.

sections.title: Sincerity (Cheng)
sections.content: Sincerity is the way of Heaven; achieving sincerity is the way of humans. It is the foundation of all moral and spiritual development.

sections.title: The Golden Mean
sections.content: Virtue lies in finding the perfect balance between extremes. The superior person maintains equilibrium in all situations.

sections.title: Self-Completion
sections.content: Through sincerity, one completes oneself and assists others in their completion. The sage helps all things achieve their proper nature.

funFacts: Most metaphysical of the Confucian classics
Heavily influenced Neo-Confucian cosmology
Emphasizes the cosmic dimension of human morality
Contains parallels to Daoist concepts of natural harmony

keyPrinciples.explanation: Human nature and moral order derive from Heaven's command
Genuine authenticity leads to spiritual transformation
Human moral cultivation participates in universal order

title: Spring and Autumn Annals (Chunqiu)
subtitle: The Moral Chronicle
summary: A historical chronicle of the State of Lu traditionally attributed to Confucius, demonstrating moral judgment through historical narrative.
keyConceptExplanation: History written to convey moral lessons through praise and blame of historical figures

sections.title: Rectification of Names
sections.content: Proper use of language reflects moral clarity. Calling things by their correct names reveals the moral nature of actions.

sections.title: Praise and Blame
sections.content: Historical narrative serves moral education by subtly praising virtue and condemning vice through careful word choice.

sections.title: Political Legitimacy
sections.content: Rulers earn legitimacy through virtuous conduct, not mere hereditary right. The chronicle judges rulers by moral standards.

sections.title: The Decline of Zhou
sections.content: Documents the moral and political decline of the Zhou dynasty through loss of ritual propriety and virtuous governance.

funFacts: Covers 242 years of Lu state history (722-481 BCE)
Traditional view: Confucius wrote it; modern view: compiled by various chroniclers
Generated three major commentaries: Gongyang, Guliang, and Zuo
Demonstrates Confucian belief that history teaches moral lessons

keyPrinciples.explanation: Historical narrative should convey moral evaluation
Moral lessons are taught through implication rather than direct statement
Historians have a moral duty to record truth and teach virtue

title: Book of Rites (Liji)
subtitle: The Foundation of Social Order
summary: A comprehensive guide to ritual practices, social norms, and governmental organization, emphasizing how proper conduct maintains social harmony.
keyConceptExplanation: Proper ritual conduct that maintains social order and cultivates virtue in individuals and society

sections.title: Family Rituals
sections.content: Detailed prescriptions for ceremonies marking life transitions: birth, coming of age, marriage, death, and ancestral veneration.

sections.title: Social Hierarchy
sections.content: Proper relationships between ruler and subject, father and son, husband and wife, elder and younger, friend and friend.

sections.title: Educational Principles
sections.content: Methods for moral education through ritual practice, music, and the cultivation of proper emotions and attitudes.

sections.title: Governmental Order
sections.content: How ritual principles should guide political organization and administrative practices to create harmonious governance.

funFacts: Contains the Great Learning and Doctrine of the Mean as chapters
Compiled during the Warring States period from earlier sources
Influenced Chinese social customs for over 2,000 years
Emphasizes that external ritual cultivates internal virtue

keyPrinciples.explanation: External practices shape internal character and moral development
Proper conduct by all members creates stable, peaceful society
Different roles and ranks serve the common good when properly fulfilled

title: Book of Documents (Shujing)
subtitle: The Wisdom of Ancient Sages
summary: A collection of speeches and documents from ancient Chinese rulers and ministers, presenting models of virtuous governance and moral leadership.
keyConceptExplanation: Rulers achieve legitimacy through moral virtue and concern for the people's welfare, not through force

sections.title: The Mandate of Heaven
sections.content: Heaven grants the right to rule to virtuous leaders and withdraws it from corrupt ones. Political legitimacy depends on moral character.

sections.title: Model Rulers: Yao and Shun
sections.content: Legendary sage-kings who ruled through moral example, chose successors based on virtue, and prioritized the people's welfare.

sections.title: The Duke of Zhou
sections.content: Confucius's ideal of the perfect minister who served loyally, established just institutions, and then retired from power.

sections.title: Virtuous Administration
sections.content: Government officials should be selected for virtue and competence, not birth or wealth. They must serve the people, not themselves.

funFacts: One of the Five Classics traditionally associated with Confucius
Contains documents spanning over 1,500 years of Chinese history
Many documents are later compositions but represent ancient ideals
Established the concept of the Mandate of Heaven in Chinese political thought

keyPrinciples.explanation: Political authority must be based on virtue, not mere power
Rulers exist to serve the welfare of the people
Officials should be chosen for virtue and ability

title: Book of Changes (Yijing/I Ching)
subtitle: The Patterns of Transformation
summary: An ancient divination text based on 64 hexagrams, later interpreted as a philosophical work on the patterns of change in nature and human affairs.
keyConceptExplanation: Reality is characterized by constant change following predictable patterns, which the wise person learns to understand and follow

sections.title: The Trigrams and Hexagrams
sections.content: Eight basic patterns (trigrams) of broken and unbroken lines combine to form 64 hexagrams representing all possible situations.

sections.title: Yin and Yang
sections.content: The interplay of feminine (yin) and masculine (yang) principles drives all change. Balance and complementarity are essential.

sections.title: The Superior Person
sections.content: The wise person studies the patterns of change to align with the cosmic order and act appropriately in each situation.

sections.title: Moral Transformation
sections.content: Understanding natural change patterns helps in moral development and social harmony. Personal cultivation follows cosmic principles.

funFacts: Originally a divination manual, later became philosophical text
Confucian commentaries (Ten Wings) transformed its interpretation
Influenced both Confucian and Daoist thought
Carl Jung studied it as a guide to psychological types and change

keyPrinciples.explanation: All phenomena undergo constant transformation according to natural patterns
Human actions should align with natural and cosmic principles
Wisdom lies in understanding each situation and responding appropriately

title: Book of Poetry/Odes (Shijing)
subtitle: The Songs of Moral Instruction
summary: A collection of 305 poems including folk songs, court music, and religious hymns, which Confucius used for moral and aesthetic education.
keyConceptExplanation: Poetry stimulates proper emotions, teaches virtue through beauty, and refines character through aesthetic appreciation

sections.title: Folk Songs (Feng)
sections.content: Songs from various regions expressing the joys and sorrows of ordinary people, teaching about human nature and social conditions.

sections.title: Court Music (Ya)
sections.content: Formal poetry used in court ceremonies and banquets, expressing ideals of proper governance and social relationships.

sections.title: Religious Hymns (Song)
sections.content: Sacred songs used in ancestral temples and religious ceremonies, connecting human virtue with cosmic order.

sections.title: Moral Instruction
sections.content: Confucius found moral lessons in the poems, teaching that literature should 'stimulate the mind, help observation, promote sociability, and regulate resentment.'

funFacts: Confucius supposedly selected these 305 from over 3,000 poems
Used as educational texts for teaching virtue and proper emotions
Includes love songs, political satire, and agricultural celebrations
First great anthology of Chinese poetry

keyPrinciples.explanation: Beauty and art are essential for complete moral development
Poetry helps cultivate proper feelings and emotional responses
Literature can critique society while maintaining cultural values

title: Family Sayings of Confucius (Kongzi Jiayu)
subtitle: Extended Teachings and Dialogues
summary: A collection of longer conversations and teachings of Confucius, providing more detailed context for his philosophical views and educational methods.
keyConceptExplanation: Confucius taught through dialogue, example, and gradual guidance rather than systematic exposition

sections.title: Educational Philosophy
sections.content: Teaching should be adapted to each student's nature and ability. 'I never refuse instruction to anyone who has sought it eagerly.'

sections.title: Character Formation
sections.content: Detailed discussions of how to cultivate virtue, overcome personal flaws, and develop moral wisdom through practice.

sections.title: Political Wisdom
sections.content: Extended conversations about governance, showing how moral principles apply to practical political problems.

sections.title: Daily Conduct
sections.content: Specific guidance on behavior in family relationships, social interactions, and professional responsibilities.

funFacts: Provides longer, more detailed conversations than the Analects
Shows Confucius's pedagogical methods in action
Contains biographical information about the Master's life
Later compilation but preserves early Confucian educational traditions

keyPrinciples.explanation: Education must be adapted to each person's specific needs and abilities
Virtue is developed through habitual right action, not just theoretical knowledge
Moral cultivation is a lifelong process requiring patience and persistence

title: Mencius (Mengzi)
subtitle: The Development of Confucian Idealism
summary: Though by Confucius's philosophical heir Mencius, this text develops key Confucian themes about human nature, virtue, and governance through extensive dialogues.
keyConceptExplanation: All humans are born with innate moral sentiments that, if properly cultivated, naturally develop into full virtue

sections.title: The Four Beginnings
sections.content: All humans possess innate feelings of compassion, shame, respect, and right/wrong that are the seeds of the four cardinal virtues.

sections.title: Moral Cultivation
sections.content: Like plants needing proper conditions to grow, moral nature requires education, practice, and proper environment to flourish.

sections.title: Benevolent Government
sections.content: True political authority comes from moral virtue and concern for people's welfare. Rulers who oppress lose legitimacy.

sections.title: The People's Welfare
sections.content: Government exists for the people's benefit. If rulers fail in their duties, the people have the right to rebel.

funFacts: Became one of the Four Books in Neo-Confucian education
Presents Confucian political philosophy in systematic form
Influenced concepts of popular sovereignty and just revolution
Contains famous analogies like the child falling into a well

keyPrinciples.explanation: Human moral nature is originally good and can be cultivated
Government legitimacy depends on serving the people's welfare
Political power should be based on virtue, not force
